channel.title: BBC News - England
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Heatwave swimming warning after six die in England
item.description: Rescuers say that lakes and rivers can be a silent summer killer after deaths around England.

item.title: Colin Pitchfork: Double killer will not be on sex offenders register
item.description: The government says Colin Pitchfork, who raped and murdered two girls, will be subject to other "strict" conditions.

item.title: 19 July: England Covid restrictions ease as PM urges caution
item.description: There is no limit on how many people can meet, nightclubs can reopen and large events can resume.

item.title: 19 July: The station where masks are mandatory - and not
item.description: Commuters at Farringdon station react to the varying face-covering rules now in place in London.

item.title: Lakota nightclub reopens to sell-out crowd in Bristol
item.description: People lined the streets as Lakota in Bristol opened its doors for the first time in 16 months.

item.title: Covid-19: Vauxhall's Luton plant reduces shifts due to staff isolating
item.description: The vehicle manufacturer says it cannot operate at full capacity due to the number of staff "pinged".

item.title: Police officer Denim Wade dismissed for avoiding self-isolation
item.description: The constable helped detain a suspect who later tested positive for coronavirus.

item.title: Man dies in fall from rocks on Jurassic Coast in Dorset
item.description: The man was pronounced dead at the scene on the Dorset coast.

item.title: Post Office Horizon scandal: More subpostmasters cleared
item.description: The Court of Appeal clears 12 more former subpostmasters who were wrongly convicted.

item.title: Bridgnorth toddler starts treatment after bone marrow donor match
item.description: A match for one-year-old Gunner, from Bridgnorth, is tracked down in Germany after a global search.

item.title: Covid: Newquay businesses mixed on lifting restrictions
item.description: Businesses, locals and holidaymakers react to most Covid restrictions being lifted.

item.title: Covid: Businesses reflect on 2021 as restrictions ease
item.description: A number of bosses tell the BBC what it was like to operate this year during the pandemic.

item.title: England nightclubs reopen: Cheers and celebrations as clubbers return for first night out
item.description: For some revellers in Leeds, this was the first time they'd ever been to a nightclub.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Knife crime: Mum tells teenagers about her sonâ€™s murder
item.description: Jean Foster has been talking to young people about the consequences of carrying a knife.

item.title: TikTok: Dog training tips from 'small-town Essex boy'
item.description: Adam's videos on looking after dogs have attracted more than a million followers during lockdown.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How are young people responding to the jab?
item.description: The Covid vaccine is now being offered to all over 18s. So what has uptake been like for young people?

item.title: Acrobatic rat climbs washing line for food
item.description: The tightrope-walking rodent was caught on camera trying to reach some bird feeders.

item.title: 'If the boat sinks I'll still be smiling'
item.description: A man who spent five months living in a London doorway makes his new home on a renovated boat.

item.title: Whipsnade Zoo to survey trees after escaped bears shot dead
item.description: The bears used a fallen tree to climb out of their enclosure and attack a boar.

item.title: Why you shouldn't get a second Covid jab too early
item.description: A government scientific advisor tells Newsbeat why four weeks is too soon between Covid jabs.

item.title: Covid rules: How can the clinically vulnerable stay safe?
item.description: As social-distancing and other Covid rules end in England, how can people who were shielding stay safe?

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: How many cases in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant first identified in India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Euro 2020 final: FA announces independent review into Wembley security breaches
item.description: The Football Association says it is determined to ensure the "disgraceful scenes" that marred the Euro 2020 final at Wembley are "never able to be repeated".

item.title: Lewis Hamilton racially abused online after British Grand Prix win
item.description: Lewis Hamilton is the target of racist abuse on social media after his victory in Sunday's British Grand Prix.

item.title: Mick Harford: Luton Town assistant to receive treatment for prostate cancer
item.description: Luton Town assistant manager Mick Harford is to receive treatment for prostate cancer after being diagnosed in December.

item.title: Derby County: Rams appeal to EFL to relax rules on player registration
item.description: Derby County, who are under a transfer embargo and short of players, appeal to the EFL to relax their registration rules.

item.title: Olivia Breen: World champion para-athlete left angry after official said her shorts were 'too revealing'
item.description: Double world champion para-athlete Olivia Breen said she was left angry and speechless after being told to wear 'more appropriate' shorts.
